instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL>
threads.message: All PM_SLP_(S5, S4, S3, S0)_L are missing. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.61v, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.33v, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 3.412v. We're using a real 85w MagSafe. Board suffered liquid damage, but sadly this is all we know.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present and steady? If so, usual suspects <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, JTAG, traces near BIOS, SPI resistors crap under SMC etc.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Oddly, I used to have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, but no longer. It's at 0.057v, though I still have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. Already replaced the SMC. The JTag has already been removed, and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> already replaced with new one. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> seems to be alright, no damage near it, and no shorts. SPI resistor traces are good. Traces near BIOS already repaired.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Missing <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is a problem. Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL>
